tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter for sleep.


We will  take a look at the different types of over-the-counter sleep aids.

Then, answer a few questions to figure out what will work best for you based on why you need a sleep aid in the first place.

For instance, if you need a sleep aid because you work night shifts, melatonin may come in handy.

If you need one because you have a big day tomorrow that require mental alertness, you may want to stay away from diphenhydramine sleep aids.

Let's figure out what will work best for you.
tabs.header:
OK. Why do you need a sleep aid?

Choose why from the common reasons below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: I need to fall asleep quicker
Wake up early. Can't go back to sleep.
I wake up too often at night
Big day tomorrow. I need some sleep.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

Please go back and choose what closely relate to what you are experiencing and see what we recommend over-the-counter.
mode.2: Something to prevent sleep?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have this sleeplessness really bad.

Your best bet would be to visit the nearest urgent care clinic or see your healthcare provider.
mode.4: Selection require an antihistamine sleep aid.
mode.5: Selection require antihistamine with painrelief combination sleep aids.
mode.6: Selection require melatonin.
mode.7: Selection require valerian sleep aid.
mode.8: Selection require a combination type of sleep aid.
mode.9: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine with pain relief sleeping pills.
mode.10: Symptoms require antihistamine and/or melatonin
mode.11: Symptoms require antihistamine and/or valerian.
mode.12: Symptoms require antihistamine and/or combination sleep aids.
mode.13: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief and / or melatonin
mode.14: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief and / or valerian.
mode.15: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief and / or combination sleep aids
mode.16: Symptoms require melatonin and / or valerian
mode.17: Symptoms require melatonin or combination sleep aids
mode.18: Symptoms require valerian or combination sleep aids
mode.19: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or melatonin
mode.20: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or valerian
mode.21: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or combination sleep aids
mode.22: Symptoms require antihistamine and / or melatonin and / or valerian
mode.23: Symptoms require antihistamine and / or melatonin and / or a combination sleep aid
mode.24: Symptoms require antihistamine and / or valerian or combination sleep aid
mode.25: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief combo and / or melatonin and / or valerian.
mode.26: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief combo and / or melatonin or combination sleep aid.
mode.27: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief combo and / or valerian or combination sleep aid
mode.28: Symptoms require melatonin, valerian or combination sleep aid.
mode.29: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or melatonin and / or valerian
mode.30: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or melatonin or combination sleep aid.
mode.31: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief and / or valerian or combination sleep aid.
mode.32: Symptoms require antihistamine and / or melatonin, valerian or combination sleep aid.
mode.33: Symptoms require antihistamine + pain relief and / or melatonin, valerian or combination sleep aid.
mode.34: Symptoms require antihistamine or antihistamine + pain relief combo, melatonin, valerian or combination sleep aids.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/26/2016 at 10:01:am

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antihistamines induce drowsiness by blocking histamine produced by the central nervous system. This side effect of drowsiness is what will make you sleepy.

Diphenhydramine and doxylamine are the common antihistamines used as sleep aids. There are subtle differences between the two. Be sure to check the comparison section for a great way to choose a sleep aid that will work best for you.

Tolerance to antihistamines as a sleep aid can develop quickly. Use them 2 to 3 nights at a time or they won't work for you after a few uses.

Take a look at the "know this" section for common side effects and things to avoid while taking an antihistamine for sleep.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine + Pain relievers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antihistamines are commonly combined with pain relievers. This is useful if you had a busy day, came down with a headache and want something to give you a good night's sleep. Good examples are:

Acetaminophen + Diphenhydramine

Use this if you have a headache and this headache is keeping you from sleeping.

Ibuprofen or Naproxen + Diphenhydramine

Use this if you have body aches and muscle pain and you are afraid this will keep you up. This combination provides and anti-inflammatory pain relief with a sleep aid.

Now, do not use these for more than 3 nights at a time. That is easy to say. What if you can't sleep after 3 nights? I suggest you see a doctor. But before then, go with melatonin. See if that would help. This is a good reason while you should use the comparison section of this app to compare sleep aids and see what will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Melatonin click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Melatonin may help with difficulty falling asleep and or staying asleep. It can tell your body it is time to go to sleep and as such, it is the sleep aid of choice in jet lags and shift work.

Look for synthetic melatonin. We discourage natural ones. Natural melatonin is made from the pineal gland of animals and this can be easily contaminated with a virus or something. This is an instance where natural doesn't mean safe to take.

collapsable.title: Valerian click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Valerian root or stem is used as a sleep aid for sleeplessness and nervous tensions. It is more useful for sleep when you are going through anxiety or stress related situations.

Know that formulations of valerian can vary in composition among manufacturers and even with the same manufacturer it can vary with different lots, date of manufacture and so on. This is because levels of constituents vary among plant and even depends on when the plant was harvested.

Be sure to look for a good manufacturer to buy from.

collapsable.title: Others click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These are used in combination with other sleep aids.

They include chamomile, lemon balm leaf extract, hops extract.....

Be sure to compare sleep aids using our comparison table.

collapsable.title: Staying Awake click to collapse contents
Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antihistamines induce drowsiness by blocking histamine produced by the central nervous system. This side effect of drowsiness is what will make you sleepy.

Diphenhydramine and doxylamine are the common antihistamines used as sleep aids. There are subtle differences between the two. Be sure to check the comparison section for a great way to choose a sleep aid that will work best for you.

Tolerance to antihistamines as a sleep aid can develop quickly. Use them 2 to 3 nights at a time or they won't work for you after a few uses.

Take a look at the "know this" section for common side effects and things to avoid while taking an antihistamine for sleep.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine + Pain relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antihistamines are commonly combined with pain relievers. This is useful if you had a busy day, came down with a headache and want something to give you a good night's sleep. 


Good examples are:

Acetaminophen + Diphenhydramine

Use this if you have a headache and this headache is keeping you from sleeping.

Ibuprofen or Naproxen + Diphenhydramine

Use this if you have body aches and muscle pain and you are afraid this will keep you up. This combination provides and anti-inflammatory pain relief with a sleep aid.

Now, do not use these for more than 3 nights at a time. That is easy to say. What if you can't sleep after 3 nights? I suggest you see a doctor. But before then, go with melatonin. See if that would help. This is a good reason while you should use the comparison section of this app to compare sleep aids and see what will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Melatonin click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Melatonin may help with difficulty falling asleep and or staying asleep. It can tell your body it is time to go to sleep and as such, it is the sleep aid of choice in jet lags and shift work.

Look for synthetic melatonin. We discourage natural ones. Natural melatonin is made from the pineal gland of animals and this can be easily contaminated with a virus or something. This is an instance where natural doesn't mean safe to take.

collapsable.title: Valerian click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Valerian root or stem is used as a sleep aid for sleeplessness and nervous tensions. It is more useful for sleep when you are going through anxiety or stress related situations.

Know that different formulation of valerian can vary in composition among manufacturers and even with the same manufacturer it can vary with different lots, date of manufacture and so on. This is because levels of constituents vary among plant and even depends on when the plant was harvested.

Be sure to look for a good manufacturer to buy from.

collapsable.title: Combination click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These are used in combination with other sleep aids.

They include chamomile, lemon balm leaf extract, hops extract.....

Be sure to compare sleep aids using our comparison table.

irregular.content: Now, use this information to choose an over-the-counter sleep aid that will work best for you.

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to collapse contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Is this for a male or a female?

We may have to approach this hair loss management based on gender.

mode.1:
Male.
Alright. Remember we are dealing with male pattern hair loss.

The best way to approach this would be:
mode.2:
Female.
Let's see what is available over the counter for female hair loss below.

The best way to approach this would be:

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on : 08/29/2014 at 11:40:am
Last updated by pharmacist on : 10/24/2014 at 07:25:am

collapsable.title: Minoxidil click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect an uphill battle with this. It will take time to get results.

You are looking at upward of 6 months.

Again, it is not something you can apply anytime you want. When you start, you will need to stay with it for no less than 6 months. Or else you will just be wasting your money.

You will typically see results only at the crown of the head.

collapsable.title: Ketoconazole click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Even though this is for dandruff, it helps to handle the inflammation of your scalp which may prevent hair from growing even if you use a growth stimulant.

It can also help reduce the sensitivity of the hair follicles to the effect of DHT.

collapsable.title: Inhibit DHT click to expand contents
collapsable.content: To do this, you will need a prescription drug like finasteride (Propecia®), dutasteride (Avodart®).

collapsable.title: Biotin click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
A vitamin that can stimulate hair growth.

Assuming you are not prone to acne, 5,000 mcg per day of biotin can give you good results.

Read the "Know this" and "what if" sections for more information on the side effects to expect.

Make sure you are drinking lots of water while taking it.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Tricomin® 

Stimulates hair growth and also helps with conditioning the hair.

This may help in a case of thin hair. But don't expect hair growth in places without hair. Think of it as a filler to make the hair feel fuller.

Spironolactone cream (5%)

This block DHT from reaching the hair follicle

collapsable.content: Summarize your recommendation

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over-the-counter for dandruff.

With dandruff, the goal is to control it. You may have to try different things before you find what is working for you.

You will also need patience and stay with a medication to be able to keep it under control.
For instance, medications like salicylic acid act by causing the outer layer of the skin on the scalp to loosen and shed.

When this happens, the dandruff will obviously get worse for the first 1 or 2 weeks before it gets better.

If you are not patient, you will get discouraged and abandon this therapy. 

Alright, let's start by taking a look at how the medications available over-the-counter for dandruff works.

This will give you enough information to take control of things.
tabs.header:
How would you describe this dandruff situation of yours right now?


Choose the nature of this dandruff from the list below and see what is recommended to use over the counter.
fieldset: Pretty much a mild case of dandruff
Scalp is painful and very red
Areas on scalp drain fluid or pus.
I do have color treated hair

mode.1: Something to prevent?
mode.2:
All of these?
You must have this dandruff really bad.

You will need to see a doctor for this dandruff. This is pretty bad.
mode.3: Selection require a mild approach.
mode.4: Selection require a moderate approach to manage this dandruff.
mode.5: Selection require a top of the line approach.
mode.6: Selection require a careful approach.
mode.7: Selection require seeing a doctor.
mode.10: Symptoms require a mild approach and carefully managing the hair.
mode.11: Symptoms require a mild approach and you will have to see adoctor
mode.13: Symptoms require a moderate approach and careful hair care.
mode.14: Symptoms require a moderate case approach and you will have to see a doctor.
mode.15: Symptoms require a severe dandruff management approach and carefully managing the hair.
mode.16: Symptoms require a severe dandruff management system and requires seeing a doctor.
mode.17: Symptoms require careful hair care management and you will have to see a doctor.
mode.23: Symptoms require mild approach, careful hair care and seeing a doctor.
mode.26: Symptoms require moderate approach, carefully managing the hair and a doctor visit.
mode.27: Symptoms require severe case management and a doctor office visit.
mode.34:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

Please choose what closely describe your dandruff and see what we recommend to use over-the-counter.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 02/15/2016 at 10:59:am

collapsable.title: Antifungal agents click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These serve to remove or reduce yeast or the fungus (Malassezia furfur) on the scalp that can cause dandruff.

Examples include ketoconazole, pyrithione zinc, selenium sulfide shampoos.

collapsable.title: Antibacterial click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
They reduce bacterial count on the scalp that can hasten the death of skin cells of the scalp.

Example include Zinc pyrithione (ZPT).

collapsable.title: Keratolytic agents click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Causes the outer layer of the skin to soften, loosen and shed thereby reducing skin flakes and scales.

Examples include salicylic acid, sulfur.

collapsable.title: keratoplastics click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Slows down the over production of skin cells on the scalp.

Slows the death and flaking off of skin cells on the scalp. 

Examples include coal tar, salicylic acid, sulfur.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
Use a gentle shampoo daily to prevent oiliness and flaky build up.

Use an antifungal shampoo like ketoconazole or selenium sulfide once or twice a week to control the fungal count on the scalp

collapsable.title: Managing a mild case. click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Start with:

Salicylic acid + sulfur or coal tar.

You need to soften the outer layer of the skin, loosen it and make it shed. 

This should reduce skin flakes and scales.

Then:    

Use zinc pyrithione for control. This should keep the bacteria count on the scalp in check. Bacteria can hasten the death of skin cells of the scalp.

Or if not too bad, use emollients like lanolin to keep the scalp hydrated.

collapsable.title: Managing a moderate case. click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Start with:

Salicylic acid, sulfur or coal tar to soften,

 loosen the outer layer of the skin on the scalp. You need to reduce skin flakes and scales.

Then:

Once you are confident the outer skin layer is cleared, use an antifungal agent like selenium sulfide or ketoconazole to keep the fungi population in check. 2 weeks of use should take care of this.

You can then maintain hydration with an emollient like lanolin.

collapsable.title: Approach to severe cases. click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Start by

Taking out the top dead cells layer of the scalp.

This will allow other medications to penetrate the skin and act.

To do this, you will use salicylic acid, sulfur or coal tar for about 2 weeks.

Know that it is going to appear worse because these agents are scalp scrubbers.

After 2 weeks

Switch to ketoconazole, selenium sulfide or  zinc pyrithione containing medications to kill or reduce the fungi or yeast population on the scalp for another 2 weeks.

Then

Use emollients like lanolin to help keep the scalp hydrated.

collapsable.title: Oily, dry, blonde or colored? click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Oily?

Prefer salicylic acid and or coal tar for taking out the flakes and scales.

Dry?

If the scalp is dry, stay away from these two. They will make things worse.

Blonde, chemical or color treated?

Avoid selenium sulfide. Go with ketoconazole or zinc pyrithione instead.

collapsable.title: See A Doctor. click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to see a doctor.

Looking at serious inflammation that will require the use of topical steroids which are not available over-the-counter.  

May also be looking at possible scalp infection that will require a good evaluation by the physician.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Keep in mind that dandruff is a chronic condition. It cannot be cured. Your focus should be on control.

Once under control, focus on maintenance to prevent it from getting worse.

irregular.content: Let's use this information to choose a good over-the-counter remedy based on the nature of this dandruff.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter for this head lice.

We will approach this in the context of an overall lice management program.

Remember, if you did not find any egg or lice, you do not need to treat. Just wait another day and look again for head lice or nits or use the wet combing technique for a more detailed check. 

There are different treatment approaches to getting rid of head lice.

For instance, your child may be very sensitive to insecticides on the hair, you may not have time to be combing, combing, combing or even just having a long hair will eliminate a treatment type.

Here is an overview of available over-the-counter lice treatment options. Take a look and see how they work.
tabs.header:
Which of these listed below apply to you right now?

Choose what applies to you from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: Found a few head lice. I am freaking out!
This is very bad. A severe case.
I want the best over-the-counter approach.
I prefer natural products. Don't want pediculicides on my hair.
Tried over-the-counter already. Still no result.
I thought it was gone. Now it is back with a vengeance!
I am thinking pesticide resistant lice.
I do have crusty, oozing bumps on the scalp.
Don't want to mess with this. Money is not a factor for me.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

Please choose what closely relate to what your child is experiencing and see what is available over-the-counter to use.
mode.2: Something to prevent head lice?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have this lice really bad.

Your best bet would be to visit the nearest urgent care clinic. if you don't think so, here is what we recommend to use over-the-counter.

This is pretty bad. Your child needs to see a pediatrician for this.
mode.4: Selection require using pediculicides to kill the lice.
mode.5: Selection require a natural approach.
mode.6: Selection require you to outsource this to a lice removal professional.
mode.7: Selection require a visit to the doctor's office.
mode.8: Symptoms require pediculicides or natural approach.
mode.9: Symptoms require using pediculicides or outsourcing to a lice treatment professional.
mode.10: Symptoms require using pediculicides, but prefer seeing a healthcare provider.
mode.11: Symptoms require a natural approach or outsourcing this to a lice removal professional
mode.12: Symptoms require a natural approach. but seeing a doctor is prefered.
mode.13: Symptoms require outsourcing to a lice treatment professional or a visit to the doctor's office.
mode.14: Symptoms require using pediculicides, or a natural approach or outsourcing to a lice removal professional.
mode.15: Symptoms require using pediculicides, or natural approaches. But we prefer a doctor visit.
mode.16: Symptoms require pediculicides, or outsourcing to a lice treatment professional or a doctor office visit.
mode.17: Selection require a natural approach, or outsourcing to a lice removal professional or a visit to the doctor.
mode.18: Symptoms require pediculicides, or a natural approach, or outsourcing or a doctor visit.
mode.50: Oops!,You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 02/15/2016 at 03:58:pm

collapsable.title: Insecticides click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Lice are basically insects that use humans as a host.

You need insecticides to kill them.

The insecticides safe to use on humans are permethrin and pyrethrins.

Examples include 1% permethrin (Nix®, store brands), pyrethrins (Rid®, store brands).

collapsable.title: Dimethicone 4% click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This coats the lice in silicone oil depriving them of human blood and ultimately death.

This may be useful if you don't want insecticides on the hair. But there are disadvantages.

Example is LiceMD®

collapsable.title: Sodium Chloride 1% click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Basically salt water, the goal here is to desiccate the lice (draw water from their cells by osmosis).

This may lead to their death if done properly. 

An example is LiceFree®

collapsable.title: Cetaphil Cleanser click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Idea is to smother the lice by coating them in Cetaphil cleanser and drying the cleanser on the head.

Example Nuvo

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
Pediculicides click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1% permethrin (Nix), or pyrethrins + piperonyl butoxide (Rid) or store brands are the pediculicides available over-the-counter for head lice.

Nix, Rid or Store brands. Like to know which to use?

  1. Allergic to ragweed or chrysanthemums?
    If yes, get the 1% permethrin.
    Pyrethrins are naturally occurring extracts from the chrysanthemum flower.
  2.  Plan on using this on a child less than 2 years old?
    Go with 1% permethrin lotion or cream.
    Pyrethrins are not recommended for use on children less than 2 years old.
  3. Don't plan on repeating the process in a week?
    You should re-apply both in a week for best results.
    None of them will kill the eggs.

Nix® website says kills the eggs. What they mean is that permethrin has a residual activity on the scalp which will help get rid of  any newly hatched baby lice from the eggs for up to 14 days.

Don't depend on this. Re-apply it after a week.

If you seriously want to eliminate the lice, these manufacturers depend on you combing out the nits, live and dead lice every single day.

If you slack on combing, you may not succeed the first time around.

To make combing frustration free, invest in a good metal nit comb. If it is plastic, be ready to get frustrated.

collapsable.title: Natural Approach click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This will assume you don't want to use insecticides on your hair.

Natural lice treatment aids might sound very good.

You may want to answer a few questions before deciding on one.

Do you intend to use this on a long hair?    

Stay away from dimethicone (LiceMD). It can be messy. 

It will be a pain getting the gel out if you have long hair.

See it as rubbing silicone gel on your hair. It can cake and you will end up swearing a lot.

If you have short hair, you may give it a try.

Know that all over-the-counter remedies depend on you combing, combing and combing to achieve any result and avoid treatment failure.

Want to avoid a dull, flat looking hair day after treatment?    

Then stay away from Cetaphil cleanser method.

The Cetaphil cleanser method (Nuvo®) can make your hair look dull and flat after treatment.

Here is a brief rundown on these natural products before you start running to get them.

  • They all depend on you combing and combing for up to 10 days straight to get the nits and live or dead lice out.
  • Your chances of failure are higher if you have long hair. You may have to cut the hair first.
  • Invest in a good metal comb.
    Most do come with a good metal comb, however.
  • You will have to repeat application for up to 3 times for good results or the lice will come back with a vengeance.

collapsable.title: Outsourcing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
May want to outsource if you have a large household that needs to be treated.

See it as hiring a cleaning service - To come and clean your household's hair of lice!

Getting rid of head lice is a major process that requires diligence, time and care. Washing hair, combing, cleaning the household items.

If you decide to go this route, look for:

  • Specific pricing information.
  • Hidden fees, such as travel fees.
  • Hourly or per person charging.
  • Aftercare process.
  • Guarantee terms.

collapsable.title: See a Doctor. click to expand contents
collapsable.content: You will need a prescription lice treatment lotion or cream.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Remember

First thing is to check everyone in the household.

It can take up to 3 weeks before you realize there is a lice problem.

The longer someone has it in the house, the greater the chance it has already spread to other members of the household.

Moreover, doing this would help you estimate how many lice shampoo / lotion to get should you decide to go that route.

You don't want to start running back and forth to the pharmacy.

Hope you figured out what will work best for you.

See the 'Know this'  and 'What if' sections above for more information.

Contact me with any questions.

irregular.content: Let's use this information to choose a good over the counter remedy and prevent any lice treatment failure.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

  • Share your treatment outcome with others.
  • Add to the recommendation.
